Existence of a certain diffeomorphism [imath]f[/imath] of [imath]\mathbb R^n[/imath] s.t. [imath]f^{*}\omega_0=\omega_0[/imath], [imath]\omega_{0}[/imath] is the standard volume form on [imath]\mathbb R^n[/imath]

Consider [imath]\mathbb{R}^n[/imath] with the standard volume form [imath]\omega_{0}:=dx_1\wedge ...\wedge dx_n[/imath] .  Let [imath]r[/imath] and [imath]R[/imath] be two positive real numbers, with [imath]R > r[/imath] .  Show that for every [imath]a, b \in B (0, r )[/imath], there exists a diffeomorphism [imath]f[/imath] of [imath]\mathbb{R}^n[/imath] such that [imath]f(a) = b , f(x)= x[/imath] for [imath]|| x || > R[/imath] and [imath]f ^{*}\omega_{0} = \omega_{0}[/imath].
One-dimensional case is fine. I have tried to extend that idea to the higher dimensional case. I have an exam. I don't understand how to construct [imath]f[/imath]. Hints are welcomed. Can anyone please help me?

When you write, "I have an exam", do you mean this question is an exam question?
It's a potential problem for the exam.

[imath]\newcommand{\Reals}{\mathbf{R}}[/imath]Hint: Let [imath](r, \theta)[/imath] denote polar coordinates on [imath]\Reals^{2}[/imath]. If [imath]\phi:(0, \infty) \to \Reals[/imath] is an arbitrary smooth function, the formula
[imath]
f(r, \theta) = \bigl(r, \theta + \phi(r)\bigr)
[/imath]
defines a "rotational shear" mapping that is smooth and area-preserving.

If [imath]b=(r_1,\phi), a=(r,\phi_1)[/imath], then [imath]f(a) \neq b[/imath],as [imath]f[/imath] preserves the distance from origin.Then how should I use this function?
You might put the origin of your polar coordinate system at the midpoint [imath]O = \frac{1}{2}(a + b)[/imath], for example.
